abstract.p: Town of Greenburgh, NY, reportedly is considering buying wind-generated energy to supplement other sources, 12th municipality in Westchester County to do so (S)

block.p: The Town of Greenburgh is considering buying wind-generated energy to supplement other sources, Supervisor Paul J. Feiner said.

If the town board decides to buy the renewable wind energy, Greenburgh would become the 12th municipality in Westchester County to do so, joining Ardsley, Bedford, Briarcliff Manor, Croton-on-Hudson, Lewisboro, New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Pound Ridge, Tarrytown and Yorktown.
The Town of Greenburgh is considering buying wind-generated energy to supplement other sources, Supervisor Paul J. Feiner said.

If the town board decides to buy the renewable wind energy, Greenburgh would become the 12th municipality in Westchester County to do so, joining Ardsley, Bedford, Briarcliff Manor, Croton-on-Hudson, Lewisboro, New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Pound Ridge, Tarrytown and Yorktown.

Greenburgh plans to buy 3 percent of its annual electricity in the form of wind power, with the annual additional cost per household, 13 cents on a typical tax bill, Mr. Feiner said. Last year the town spent $224,000 for all of its energy, Jim Heslop, Greenburgh's comptroller, said.
In general, wind energy costs about 2 percent more than traditional forms.

In addition, State Assemblywoman Sandra R. Galef, Democrat of Ossining, has sponsored a bill to permit municipalities to spend up to 15 percent more to buy electricity from renewable energy sources. The legislation has passed the Assembly, but has yet to come to a vote in the Senate.
